metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: 30m month compositing Leaf Area Index (LAI) product of the Heihe River Basin
metadata.description: The 30 m / month synthetic leaf area index (LAI) data set of Heihe River basin provides the monthly Lai synthetic products from 2011 to 2014. This data uses the domestic satellite HJ / CCD data with high time resolution (2 days after Networking) and spatial resolution (30 m) to construct the multi angle observation data set. Considering the impact of surface classification and terrain fluctuation, the algorithm is selected according to the characteristics of different vegetation types Choosing a suitable parameterization scheme of integrated model, inversion Lai based on look-up table method. The remote sensing data acquired every month can provide more angles and more observations than the single day sensor data, but the quality of multi-phase and multi angle observation data is uneven due to the difference of on orbit operation time and performance of the sensor. Therefore, in order to effectively use multi temporal and multi angle observation data, a data quality inspection scheme is designed. Using the Lai ground observation data of 9 forest quadrats, 20 farmland quadrats and 14 savanna quadrats from dayokou area in the upper reaches of Heihe River and Yingke and Linze areas in the middle reaches to verify the Lai in July, the inversion results are in good agreement with the measurement results, and the average error is less than 1; in addition, the Lai inversion results of the combined multi temporal and multi angle observation data are in good agreement with the ground measurement data （R2=0.9，RMSE=0.42）。 In a word, the 30 m / month synthetic leaf area index (LAI) data set of Heihe River Basin comprehensively uses multi temporal and multi angle observation data to improve the estimation accuracy and time resolution of parameter products, so as to better serve the application of remote sensing data products.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Leaf area index (LAI) is one of the important geometric-structure parameters in terrestrial vegetation ecosystems. Accurate LAI retrieval is always a key task of such remote-sensing applications, and it is also a precondition of crop-yield estimation, vegetative evapotranspiration calculation and the energy-exchange evaluation of terrestrial vegetation (Badhwar et al., 1986; Townshend et al., 1988; Baret et al., 1991; Wood et al., 1993; Bonan, 1995; Bicheron et al., 1999; Buermann et al., 2001; Kamalesh et al., 2008). In general, there are three categories of LAI retrieval methods. The first category is experiential inversion method based on Vegetation Index (VI), such as retrieving LAI according to the correlation between the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and LAI (Turner, 1999; Brown et al., 2000; Haboudane et al., 2004; Wang et al., 2005). Although such an approach is simple and widely-used, its accuracy is very low, and some VI can easily get saturated. The second category can be called the reflectance model inversion method, by which the anisotropic effect caused by sun-object-sensor geometry can be removed, but the effect caused by background variations cannot be avoided, especially within mixed pixels. The complex background inhibits accurate LAI retrieval (Li et al., 1986; Nilson et al., 1989; Chen et al., 1997; Xu, 2005).
research objective: Based on a hybrid canopy reflectance model, a new hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) is proposed in this paper. This method can estimate LAI accurately through analyzing the canopy anisotropy. The study region was situated in Zhangye, Gansu Province, China; hyperspectral and multi-angular images of the study region were acquired via the Compact High-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer/Project for On-Board Autonomy (CHRIS/PROBA), on 4 June 2008.
challenges: The anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions constitute three factors that can strongly constrain the accuracy of retrieved LAI. As the derivative method is very sensitive to random noise, we put forward an innovative filtering approach, by which the data can be de-noised in spectral and spatial dimensions synchronously.
methods: After the pre-processing procedures, the DSD method was applied, and the retrieved LAI was validated by ground reference data at 11 sites.
dataset: The study region was situated in Zhangye, Gansu Province, China; hyperspectral and multi-angular images of the study region were acquired via the Compact High-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer/Project for On-Board Autonomy (CHRIS/PROBA), on 4 June 2008.
findings: Results show that the new LAI inversion method is accurate and effective with the aid of the innovative filtering method.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: Multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research are crucial for addressing the challenge of upscaling processes on heterogeneous surfaces. They enable the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by utilizing hierarchically nested scales and multidisciplinary data, thereby enhancing understanding and accuracy in this field.

Definition.Question: How is the leaf area index (LAI) retrieved using remote sensing techniques?
Definition.Answer: The leaf area index (LAI) is retrieved using remote sensing techniques through several methods, including the experiential inversion method based on Vegetation Index, reflectance model inversion method, and hyperspectral directional second derivative method. These methods aim to account for factors like canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variations to improve accuracy.

Definition.Question: What are some of the challenges associated with LAI retrieval using remote sensing data?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with LAI retrieval using remote sensing data include the anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions. These factors can constrain the accuracy of LAI retrieval, and innovative filtering approaches are often required to de-noise data and improve precision.

Comparison.Question: How do the data quality control measures in the multiscale dataset from HiWATER compare to those used in the 黑河流域30m/月合成叶面积指数（LAI）数据集?
Comparison.Answer: Both datasets employ rigorous quality control measures, but the multiscale dataset from HiWATER emphasizes sensor calibration and a hierarchical observation system, whereas the 黑河流域30m/月合成叶面积指数（LAI）数据集 focuses on data quality checks specific to multi-angle and multi-temporal remote sensing data.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of canopy reflectance anisotropy in LAI retrieval differ from the challenges of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes?
Comparison.Answer: The challenge of canopy reflectance anisotropy primarily involves removing effects related to sun-object-sensor geometry and background variations, while challenges in multiscale observations focus on the poor availability of data across different scales and capturing interactions in heterogeneous landscapes.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of hyperspectral and multi-angular imaging in the CHRIS/PROBA dataset compare to the use of LiDAR and imaging spectrometers in the HiWATER dataset for LAI estimation?
Comparison.Answer: Both approaches utilize advanced imaging technologies to enhance LAI estimation; however, hyperspectral and multi-angular imaging from the CHRIS/PROBA dataset is focused on analyzing canopy anisotropy, while the HiWATER dataset employs LiDAR and imaging spectrometers to capture comprehensive eco-hydrological processes across multiple scales.

Interpretation.Question: How do multiscale observation strategies contribute to understanding eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Interpretation.Answer: Multiscale observation strategies, as seen in the HiWATER experiment, utilize hierarchically nested scales including instruments such as eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This allows for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes effectively, addressing the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise from using remote sensing data for leaf area index (LAI) retrieval, and how can these be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in LAI retrieval using remote sensing data include the anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and atmospheric conditions. Innovative methods, such as the hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD), can address these by analyzing canopy anisotropy and employing filtering approaches that de-noise data in spectral and spatial dimensions.

Interpretation.Question: How can data quality control measures enhance the reliability of datasets in eco-hydrological research?
Interpretation.Answer: Data quality control measures, as implemented in the collection of the HiWATER dataset, involve rigorous sensor calibration, data processing, and dataset generation processes. These measures ensure the reliability and accuracy of the data, which is crucial for its application in understanding vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the variability in the quality of multi-angle and multi-temporal observation data in eco-hydrological remote sensing?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability in the quality of multi-angle and multi-temporal observation data is primarily due to differences in the on-orbit operation time and performance of sensors. Additionally, the heterogeneous nature of the surface and the anisotropic effects caused by sun-object-sensor geometry further constrain data quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately retrieve the Leaf Area Index (LAI) using remote sensing techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Retrieving the Leaf Area Index (LAI) accurately is challenging due to the anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions. These factors, along with the sensitivity of derivative methods to random noise, significantly constrain the accuracy of LAI retrieval.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of utilizing multiscale observations for understanding eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing multiscale observations in heterogeneous landscapes, such as those implemented in the HiWATER experiment, allows for the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. This includes the ability to study interactions between different ecosystems, such as the oasis-desert system, through a hierarchically nested scale of instrumentation. This approach helps overcome the challenge of limited multiscale observation availability and provides comprehensive data that can improve the understanding of these complex processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does addressing the anisotropic effect in canopy reflectance models influence the accuracy of LAI retrieval?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Addressing the anisotropic effect in canopy reflectance models, as done with the hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD), significantly improves the accuracy of LAI retrieval. By removing the anisotropic effect caused by sun-object-sensor geometry, this method can accurately estimate LAI, even in the presence of background variations. The implementation of an innovative filtering approach to reduce random noise further enhances the reliability of LAI estimates, resulting in accurate and effective retrievals validated against ground reference data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind developing a dataset that synthesizes leaf area index (LAI) measurements from multi-angle remote sensing observations in eco-hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to enhance the accuracy and temporal resolution of LAI estimates by integrating multi-temporal and multi-angular remote sensing data, thus improving parameter product estimations and supporting the application of remote sensing data products in eco-hydrological research.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in designing a quality check scheme for multi-temporal and multi-angular remote sensing data to enhance the precision of parameter products?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To effectively utilize multi-temporal and multi-angular observation data, a data quality check scheme is first designed. This involves considering the differences in the quality of the observation data due to the varied in-orbit operation time and performance of the sensors. The scheme incorporates ground observation data from different land types such as forests, farmlands, and sparse grasslands to validate the retrieved Leaf Area Index (LAI) data, ensuring that the inversion results align well with the actual measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is a hierarchical observational system structured to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The observational system is structured in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. This includes arranging instruments such as eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations in a sparse network. A superstation is constructed within the oasis, with additional towers and stations in surrounding landscapes like sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. This setup allows for intensive observations at different scales, including the irrigation district scale.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the improvement of parameter product estimation accuracy and time resolution in eco-hydrological remote sensing datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The use of multi-angle observations and data quality checks, alongside the development of integrated model parameterization schemes specific to different vegetation types, have enabled improvements in parameter product estimation accuracy and time resolution in remote sensing datasets.

Enablement.Question: Which methods are employed to enhance the accuracy of leaf area index (LAI) retrieval in remote sensing applications?
Enablement.Answer: To enhance the accuracy of LAI retrieval, methods such as the hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) and innovative filtering approaches are employed to address challenges like canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variations.

Expectation.Question: Why might some data collection methods face challenges in capturing the anisotropy of canopy reflectance accurately?
Expectation.Answer: The anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions are factors that strongly constrain the accuracy of retrieved leaf area index (LAI). These complexities can impact the reliability of data collection methods, necessitating innovative approaches to address these challenges.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using multi-angle and multi-time remote sensing data for improving LAI estimation accuracy in eco-hydrological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multi-angle and multi-time remote sensing data is considered effective in improving LAI estimation accuracy as it provides more comprehensive observation angles and times, allowing for better parameter product estimation. The integration of such data considers surface classification and topographic variations, resulting in a higher consistency with ground measurements, as indicated by a good match in LAI inversion results with a low average error and strong correlation with ground-truth data.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential benefits of using a hyperspectral directional second derivative method for LAI retrieval as compared to traditional inversion methods?
Judgmental.Answer: The hyperspectral directional second derivative method offers potential benefits over traditional inversion methods through its ability to accurately estimate LAI by analyzing canopy anisotropy. This approach addresses challenges posed by canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variability, with the added advantage of utilizing an innovative filtering method that enhances accuracy by de-noising data. This results in a more precise LAI retrieval, validated against ground reference data.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how different vegetation types influence the accuracy of Leaf Area Index (LAI) retrieval in remote sensing data.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection methods consider the characteristics of different vegetation types by choosing suitable integrated model parameterization schemes. This approach helps in accurately retrieving LAI, as it takes into account the specific traits of various vegetation types.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a data collection method that can address the variability in atmospheric conditions and background characteristics to improve the accuracy of LAI retrieval.
Request/Directive.Answer: A data collection method that addresses variability in atmospheric conditions and background characteristics involves using a hybrid canopy reflectance model combined with a hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD). This approach analyzes canopy anisotropy to improve LAI retrieval accuracy. Additionally, an innovative filtering approach is applied to de-noise data in both spectral and spatial dimensions, mitigating the impact of random noise. This method's efficacy is validated against ground reference data, highlighting its capability to handle variations in atmospheric and background conditions effectively.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets that capture leaf area index (LAI) across different vegetation types using remote sensing technologies.
Request/Directive.Answer: To expand or refine datasets capturing LAI across different vegetation types, remote sensing technologies can be leveraged through multi-angle and multispectral observations. Utilizing data from high-resolution satellites like HJ/CCD can provide increased temporal and spatial resolution. Implementing algorithms that consider surface classification and terrain variations can further enhance data accuracy. Additionally, integrating ground-based observations with airborne remote sensing data, such as LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, can provide comprehensive datasets. Strategies also include developing parameterization schemes tailored to different vegetation types and establishing quality check protocols to ensure data reliability.
